Information Disclosure.description: An attacker can brute-force file encryption because there's no defense in place (example defense, password stretching).
An attacker can see error messages with security sensitive content.
An attacker can read content because messages (say, an email or HTTP cookie) aren't encrypted even if the channel is encrypted.
An attacker may be able to read a document or data because it's encrypted with a non-standard algorithm.
An attacker can read data because it's hidden or occluded (for undo or change tracking) and the user might forget that it's there.
An attacker can act as a 'man in the middle' because you don't authenticate endpoints of a network connection.
An attacker can access information through a search indexer, logger, or other such mechanism.
An attacker can read sensitive information in a file with permissive permissions.
An attacker can read information in files or databases with no access controls.
An attacker can discover the fixed key being used to encrypt.
An attacker can read the entire channel because the channel (say, HTTP or SMTP) isn't encrypted.
An attacker can read network information because there's no cryptography used.
An attacker decrypts sensitive data transmitted over an insecure legacy protocol due to lack of proper encryption.
An attacker extracts sensitive information through error messages generated by an SQL injection vulnerability.
An attacker accesses configuration files containing sensitive data due to improper access controls on a cloud storage bucket.
Information Disclosure.MITRE ATT&CK: T1530 - Data from Cloud Storage Object

Information Disclosure.description: Sensitive data is leaked via metadata in document headers which are not stripped from documents before public release.
An attacker sniffs network traffic to read unencrypted data being transmitted between the client and the server.
An attacker utilizes directory listing vulnerabilities to discover and access unprotected files and directories on a web server.
A developer unintentionally logs sensitive information, such as passwords or API keys, in debug logs that are not secured.
An attacker takes advantage of a weakly implemented CAPTCHA allowing automated tools to scrape sensitive user data from the site.
Sensitive data is exposed to external systems through verbose HTTP referrer headers sent by the browser.
An attacker manipulates client-side caching mechanisms to retrieve sensitive information stored in cache files.
Information Disclosure.MITRE ATT&CK: T1552.004 - Unsecured Credentials in Local Storage
